fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Hilbert space H is a complete inner product space. That is, a Hilbert space is a vector space H with an inner product <\cdot ,\cdot > such that the norm defined by ||x|| = \sqrt {<x,x>} makes H into a complete metric space.
Hilbert spaces extend the methods of linear algebra to infinite-dimensional settings, making them crucial for quantum mechanics, Fourier analysis, and partial differential equations.
Examples include the space L^2 of square-integrable functions and the space l^2 of square-summable sequences.
In the context of functional analysis and Hilbert spaces, there are several different notions of a basis:

Orthonormal basis: In a Hilbert space H, an orthonormal set \{e_i\} is called an orthonormal basis if it is complete, meaning that the closed linear span of \{e_i\} is the entire space H. Equivalently, \{e_i\} is an orthonormal basis if for every vector x \in H:
fr:mainmatter.fr:ul:
x = \sum _i \langle x, e_i \rangle e_i (expansion formula)
||x||^2 = \sum _i |\langle x, e_i \rangle |^2 (Parseval's identity)
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Schauder basis: A sequence \{x_i\} in a Banach space X is called a Schauder basis if every vector x \in X can be expressed uniquely as x = \sum _{i=1}^{\infty } a_i x_i, where the coefficients a_i are scalars and the series converges in the norm of X.

Hamel basis: A set \{e_i\} in a vector space V is called a Hamel basis if every vector v \in V can be expressed uniquely as a finite linear combination v = \sum _{i=1}^n a_i e_i, where a_i are scalars. This is the algebraic notion of a basis, but in infinite-dimensional spaces, Hamel bases are typically not useful for analysis because they are uncountable and the expansions don't involve convergence of series.
For orthonormal bases in Hilbert spaces, the existence of such bases is guaranteed by the Gram-Schmidt process and Zorn's lemma, though they may be uncountable for non-separable spaces.

The closed linear span of a subset S of a normed vector space V is the closure of the linear span of S.
The linear span of S, denoted span(S), is the set of all finite linear combinations of elements in S:

fr:p.fr:tex: span(S) = \{\sum _{i=1}^n a_i v_i : n \in \mathbb {N}, a_i \in \mathbb {K}, v_i \in S\}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The closure of a set in a normed space is the set together with all its limit points. So the closed linear span of S, often denoted by \overline {span(S)}, consists of all vectors that can be approximated arbitrarily well by finite linear combinations of elements in S.

A metric space (X,d) is said to be complete if every Cauchy sequence in X converges to a point in X.
Intuitively, a metric space is complete if there are no "holes" or "missing points" in it. All the limit points of Cauchy sequences are already in the space.
Examples of complete spaces include \mathbb {R}^n with the Euclidean metric, Banach spaces, and Hilbert spaces.

If U = \{u_n : n \in \mathbb {N}\} is an orthonormal sequence of a Hilbert space H, then the following conditions are equivalent:
(a) \langle u_n, x \rangle = 0 for all n \in \mathbb {N} implies x = 0
(b) x = \sum _{n \in \mathbb {N}} \langle u_n, x \rangle u_n for all x \in H
(c) ||x||^2 = \sum _{n \in \mathbb {N}} |\langle u_n, x \rangle |^2 for all x \in H
(This is the Parseval's identity)

For an orthonormal set u_\alpha in a Hilbert space H to be a basis (or complete), it means that the set is "large enough" to represent any vector in the space.
An orthonormal sequence is complete if it's closed linear span is the whole space
A set S is countable if its elements can be arranged in a sequence (i.e., if there exists a bijection between S and the set of natural numbers \mathbb {N}, or a subset of \mathbb {N}).
Formally, a set S is countable if either:

fr:ul.fr:li: S is finite (i.e., there exists a bijection between S and \{1, 2, ..., n\} for some n \in \mathbb {N}), or
S is countably infinite (i.e., there exists a bijection between S and \mathbb {N})

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Examples of countable sets include:

fr:ul.fr:li: The set of natural numbers \mathbb {N}
The set of integers \mathbb {Z}
The set of rational numbers \mathbb {Q}
The set of algebraic numbers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In contrast, the set of real numbers \mathbb {R} is uncountable, as proven by Cantor's diagonal argument.
In functional analysis, the concept of countability is important in several contexts:

fr:ul.fr:li: A Hilbert space is separable if and only if it has a countable orthonormal basis
A Schauder basis in a Banach space is by definition countable
The spectrum of a compact operator on a Hilbert space is either finite or countably infinite with 0 as the only possible accumulation point

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The direct sum of two vector subspaces U and V of a vector space W, denoted U \oplus V, is the set of all vectors that can be uniquely expressed as the sum of a vector from U and a vector from V.
Formally, U \oplus V = \{u + v : u \in U, v \in V\} where the representation w = u + v is unique for each w \in U \oplus V.
For the direct sum to exist, the subspaces must satisfy the condition U \cap V = \{0\}, where \{0\} is the zero vector. This ensures the uniqueness of the representation.

In the context of a Hilbert space H, if M is a closed subspace, then H = M \oplus M^\perp , where M^\perp is the orthogonal complement of M. This means every vector x \in H can be uniquely written as x = m + n with m \in M and n \in M^\perp .
The dual space of a vector space V, denoted V^*, is the vector space of all linear functionals on V (i.e., linear maps from V to the underlying field).

For a normed vector space (X, ||\cdot ||), the continuous dual space or topological dual space, often still denoted X^*, consists of all bounded (or continuous) linear functionals on X. A linear functional f is bounded if there exists a constant M > 0 such that |f(x)| \leq M ||x|| for all x \in X.

The dual space plays a central role in functional analysis and helps establish important connections between a space and its "mirror image." The natural norm on the dual space X^* is the operator norm:
Some important theorems related to dual spaces include:

fr:ul.fr:li: The Hahn-Banach theorem, which guarantees the existence of continuous linear functionals with specific properties
The Banach-Alaoglu theorem, which states that the closed unit ball in the dual of a normed space is compact in the weak* topology
For Hilbert spaces H, there is a canonical isomorphism between H and its dual H^* via the Riesz representation theorem

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An inner product space is a vector space V over the field of real or complex numbers, equipped with an inner product \langle \cdot ,\cdot \rangle : V \times V \rightarrow \mathbb {F}.
The inner product satisfies the following axioms for all vectors u, v, w \in V and all scalars a \in \mathbb {F}:

fr:li.fr:tex: \langle au + v, w\rangle = a\langle u, w\rangle + \langle v, w\rangle

fr:ul.fr:li: Positive definiteness: \langle v, v\rangle \geq 0, and \langle v, v\rangle = 0 if and only if v = 0

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: From the inner product, we can define:

fr:ul.fr:li: A norm: ||v|| = \sqrt {\langle v,v\rangle }
A metric: d(u,v) = ||u-v||
The concept of orthogonality: u and v are orthogonal if \langle u,v\rangle = 0

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Common examples of inner product spaces include \mathbb {R}^n with the dot product, the space C([a,b]) with the L^2-inner product \langle f,g \rangle = \int _a^b f(x)\overline {g(x)}dx, and the space of square-integrable functions L^2.
A Hilbert space is a complete inner product space.

This expresses the fact that the basis elements are orthogonal to each other (\langle e_i, e_j \rangle = 0 for i \neq j) and have unit norm (\langle e_i, e_i \rangle = 1).
An orthonormal set S in a Hilbert space H is called maximal if there is no orthonormal set that properly contains S.

In other words, an orthonormal set S is maximal if adding any non-zero vector v \in H \setminus S would destroy the orthonormality property. This means that for any v \in H with ||v|| = 1 that is not in S, there exists some u \in S such that \langle u, v \rangle \neq 0.
A key result in the theory of Hilbert spaces states that an orthonormal set is maximal if and only if it is complete, meaning that its closed linear span equals the entire Hilbert space.
Equivalently, an orthonormal set \{e_i\} is maximal if and only if:

fr:ul.fr:li: \langle x, e_i \rangle = 0 for all i implies x = 0
Every x \in H can be expressed as x = \sum _i \langle x, e_i \rangle e_i
Parseval's identity holds: ||x||^2 = \sum _i |\langle x, e_i \rangle |^2 for all x \in H

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S be a subset of a Hilbert space H. The orthogonal complement of S, denoted S^\perp , is the set of all vectors in H that are orthogonal to every vector in S.
Formally, S^\perp = \{y \in H : \langle x, y \rangle = 0 \text { for all } x \in S\}.
Some important properties:
fr:mainmatter.fr:ul:
S^\perp is a closed subspace of H
(S^\perp )^\perp = \overline {\text {span}(S)}, where \overline {\text {span}(S)} is the closed linear span of S
H = \overline {\text {span}(S)} \oplus S^\perp , where \oplus represents the direct sum of subspaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An orthonormal sequence in a Hilbert space H is a sequence (u_n) of vectors in H such that:
1. Each vector has unit norm: ||u_n|| = 1 for all n.
2. Different vectors are orthogonal to each other: \langle u_m, u_n \rangle = 0 for all m \neq n.
Equivalently, an orthonormal sequence satisfies \langle u_m, u_n \rangle = \delta _{mn}, where \delta _{mn} is the Kronecker delta.
An orthonormal sequence is a fundamental concept in the study of Hilbert spaces and forms the basis for Fourier analysis and many approximation methods.
An orthonormal basis for a Hilbert space H is an orthonormal set \{e_i\} of vectors in H such that the closed linear span of \{e_i\} is the entire space H.

In other words, an orthonormal basis is an orthonormal set that is also complete in the sense that any vector in the Hilbert space can be approximated arbitrarily well by finite linear combinations of the basis elements.

Important properties include:

fr:ul.fr:li: Every Hilbert space has an orthonormal basis (this requires the Axiom of Choice for general Hilbert spaces)
Parseval's identity holds for orthonormal bases
Any two orthonormal bases of the same Hilbert space have the same cardinality

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An orthonormal set in a Hilbert space H is a set of vectors \{e_i\} that satisfies the following conditions:

fr:ul.fr:li: Each vector has unit norm: ||e_i|| = 1 for all i
Different vectors are orthogonal to each other: \langle e_i, e_j \rangle = 0 for all i \neq j

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Equivalently, an orthonormal set satisfies \langle e_i, e_j \rangle = \delta _{ij}, where \delta _{ij} is the Kronecker delta.

A set of vectors \{e_i\} in an inner product space is said to be orthonormal if:

fr:ul.fr:li: Each vector has unit norm: ||e_i|| = 1 for all i
Different vectors are orthogonal to each other: \langle e_i, e_j \rangle = 0 for all i \neq j

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Equivalently, a set of vectors \{e_i\} is orthonormal if \langle e_i, e_j \rangle = \delta _{ij}, where \delta _{ij} is the Kronecker delta.
Orthonormal sets have several important properties:

fr:ul.fr:li: They are linearly independent

They provide simple formulas for decomposing vectors: If \{e_i\} is an orthonormal set and x is a vector in the space, then the projection of x onto the span of \{e_i\} is P_{\text {span}\{e_i\}}(x) = \sum _i \langle x, e_i \rangle e_i
Bessel's inequality holds: For any vector x and orthonormal set \{e_i\}, \sum _i |\langle x, e_i \rangle |^2 \leq ||x||^2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Orthonormal sets are fundamental in the study of Hilbert spaces and form the basis for many results in functional analysis, such as the theory of Fourier series and orthogonal polynomials.
A complete (in the sense of Completeness of orthonormal set) orthonormal subset (orthonormal sequence) of H is also called an orthonormal basis of H
Altenately: An orthonormal basis of H is a countable maximal orthonormal subset \{e_n\} of H.
N.B.: This notion of basis is not quite the same as in the finite dimensional case (although it is a legitimate extension of it).
There are other, quite different, notions of a basis in infinite dimensions. See for instance 'Hamel basis' which arises in some settings
Every separable Hilbert space has a countable orthonormal basis.

The Riesz representation theorem has several forms, but the most common version for Hilbert spaces states:
Let H be a Hilbert space and let Ï†: H â†’ \mathbb {C} (or \mathbb {R}) be a continuous linear functional on H. Then there exists a unique vector y \in H such that:
Ï†(x) = \langle x, y \rangle for all x \in H
Furthermore, ||Ï†|| = ||y||.

This theorem establishes a canonical isomorphism between a Hilbert space H and its dual space H^*. It means that every continuous linear functional on a Hilbert space can be represented as an inner product with a unique vector in the space.
There are also Riesz representation theorems for other contexts:

fr:ul.fr:li: For measures: For certain spaces of continuous functions C(X), every positive linear functional can be represented as integration against a measure
For L^p spaces: For 1 < p < \infty , the dual of L^p is isomorphic to L^q, where \frac {1}{p} + \frac {1}{q} = 1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The theorem is used extensively in various applications, including in quantum mechanics (where observables correspond to operators and states to vectors), and in solving partial differential equations using variational methods.

A Schauder basis for a Banach space X is a sequence of vectors \{e_n\}_{n=1}^{\infty } in X such that for every vector x \in X, there exists a unique sequence of scalars \{a_n\}_{n=1}^{\infty } such that:
where the series converges in the norm of X.

A Schauder basis differs from a Hamel basis in that it allows for infinite (but convergent) linear combinations of basis elements, making it more suitable for the study of infinite-dimensional Banach spaces.

Every Schauder basis \{e_n\} comes with a sequence of coordinate functionals \{e_n^*\} in the dual space X^*, defined by e_n^*(x) = a_n, where a_n are the unique coefficients in the expansion x = \sum _{n} a_n e_n.
Important properties of Schauder bases:

fr:ul.fr:li: A Banach space with a Schauder basis is always separable
Not every separable Banach space has a Schauder basis (as proven by Per Enflo for certain spaces)
In a Hilbert space, every orthonormal basis is a Schauder basis
The standard examples of Schauder bases include the Haar system in L^p[0,1] for 1 \leq p < \infty and the trigonometric system in L^2[0,2\pi ]

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A topological space is called separable if it contains a countable, dense subset. For a metric space, this means there exists a countable subset whose closure is the entire space.

In the context of Hilbert spaces, a Hilbert space H is separable if and only if it has a countable orthonormal basis. This is equivalent to saying that there exists a countable set \{x_n\} such that the span of \{x_n\} is dense in H.
For Banach spaces, separability means there exists a countable subset whose linear span is dense in the space.
Important examples of separable spaces include:

fr:ul.fr:li: The Euclidean spaces \mathbb {R}^n and \mathbb {C}^n
The space L^p[a,b] for 1 \leq p < \infty
The space C[a,b] of continuous functions on [a,b]
The sequence spaces l^p for 1 \leq p < \infty

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Important non-separable spaces include:

fr:ul.fr:li: The space L^\infty of essentially bounded measurable functions
The space l^\infty of bounded sequences
The space of all bounded linear operators on an infinite-dimensional Hilbert space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Separability is a useful property in functional analysis as it often allows for the application of results that require countable operations, such as diagonal arguments and the ability to work with sequences rather than nets.

In functional analysis, a "space" typically refers to a vector space equipped with additional structure, such as a topology, norm, or inner product. These structures provide a framework for studying functions as vectors and for analyzing limiting operations.
Common types of spaces in functional analysis include:

fr:ul.fr:li: Vector spaces: Sets equipped with operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication that satisfy certain axioms
Metric spaces: Sets equipped with a distance function (metric) that defines the concept of nearness between elements
Normed spaces: Vector spaces equipped with a norm function that assigns a notion of length to vectors
Banach spaces: Complete normed vector spaces, where every Cauchy sequence converges
Inner product spaces: Vector spaces equipped with an inner product, which generalizes the dot product in Euclidean space
Hilbert spaces: Complete inner product spaces, combining the structures of Banach spaces and inner product spaces
Topological vector spaces: Vector spaces equipped with a topology compatible with the vector operations
Locally convex spaces: Topological vector spaces where the topology is defined by a family of seminorms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Function spaces are particularly important in functional analysis. These are spaces whose elements are functions, such as:

fr:ul.fr:li: C(X): The space of continuous functions on a topological space X
L^p: The spaces of measurable functions whose p-th power is integrable
H^k: Sobolev spaces of functions with weak derivatives up to order k

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The study of these spaces and the operators between them forms the core of functional analysis.
A metric space (X,d) is said to be complete if every Cauchy sequence in X converges to a point in X.
Intuitively, a metric space is complete if there are no "holes" or "missing points" in it. All the limit points of Cauchy sequences are already in the space.
Examples of complete spaces include \mathbb {R}^n with the Euclidean metric, Banach spaces, and Hilbert spaces.
An inner product space is a vector space V over the field of real or complex numbers, equipped with an inner product \langle \cdot ,\cdot \rangle : V \times V \rightarrow \mathbb {F}.
The inner product satisfies the following axioms for all vectors u, v, w \in V and all scalars a \in \mathbb {F}:

fr:li.fr:tex: \langle au + v, w\rangle = a\langle u, w\rangle + \langle v, w\rangle

fr:ul.fr:li: Positive definiteness: \langle v, v\rangle \geq 0, and \langle v, v\rangle = 0 if and only if v = 0

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: From the inner product, we can define:

fr:ul.fr:li: A norm: ||v|| = \sqrt {\langle v,v\rangle }
A metric: d(u,v) = ||u-v||
The concept of orthogonality: u and v are orthogonal if \langle u,v\rangle = 0

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Common examples of inner product spaces include \mathbb {R}^n with the dot product, the space C([a,b]) with the L^2-inner product \langle f,g \rangle = \int _a^b f(x)\overline {g(x)}dx, and the space of square-integrable functions L^2.
A Hilbert space is a complete inner product space.

An inner product on a vector space V over a field F (either \mathbb {R} or \mathbb {C}) is a function <\cdot ,\cdot >: V \times V \rightarrow F that satisfies the following properties for all vectors u, v, w \in V and all scalars a \in F:

fr:ul.fr:li: Conjugate symmetry: <u, v> = \overline {<v, u>} (where \overline {z} is the conjugate of z)
Positive definiteness: <v, v> \geq 0, and <v, v> = 0 if and only if v = 0

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An inner product induces a norm on the vector space via ||v|| = \sqrt {<v, v>}, which in turn defines a metric d(u, v) = ||u - v||.
